title: COUNTY FAIR QUEEN PAGEANT

full_story:
1/2/26
The 2026 Miss Illinois County Fair Queen Pageant will be held on Saturday, January 17th and Sunday the 18th in Springfield.  Clay County Fair Queen Olivia Haun will be honored at a sendoff party at the State Bank Suites Sunday from 1 to 3 pm.
The pageant happens during the annual meeting and convention of the Illinois Association of Agricultural Fairs.  With former county fair queens taking part, the actual competition on Saturday will include Speech, Swimsuit, and Evening Gown Competitions and Pageant Finals on Sunday the 18th.
The sendoff will be a come and go event.  Everyone is welcome to wish Olivia Good Luck as she heads off to represent Clay County.  T-shirt orders will also be ready for pickup at the party.
Voting for this year’s People’s Choice award winner is now open.  Through midnight January 17th, use the link in this story to make your voice count and show support for Olivia by voting.  The cost is $1 per vote and you can vote as many times as you like.  The People’s Choice winner will be announced on stage and will earn a cash scholarship.  The winner will also get to donate $500 to a charity of their choice.
Johnna Fulcher is the retiring Miss Illinois County Fair Queen.
https://illinoiscountyfairs.org/peoples-choice/

title: GROCERY TAX GONE?
brief: Illinois’ statewide 1% grocery tax went away yesterday, although many people continue to pay it at the local level. Data compiled by the Illinois Municipal League shows that 656 mu...
full_story:
1/2/26
Illinois’ statewide 1% grocery tax went away yesterday, although many people continue to pay it at the local level.
Data compiled by the Illinois Municipal League shows that 656 municipalities, a little more than half of the state’s municipalities, have passed an ordinance establishing their own grocery tax.  Those communities are home to 7.2 million people, or 56.5% of the state’s population.  Three counties, Washington, Wabash and Moultrie have also approved countywide grocery taxes.  In Clay County, Flora, Louisville and Clay City have all passed a 1% grocery tax.
Governor JB Pritzker signed a bill in 2024 eliminating the 1% statewide grocery tax, which he touted as a measure to ease residents’ tax burden.  But because the revenue from the state grocery tax went to municipal governments, rather than state coffers, the measure allowed local governments to levy their own 1% tax via ordinance, rather than a referendum to voters.

full_story:

Time is running out to vote for your favorite Flora High School Foods Class Gingerbread house.  Displays are at the Flora Public Library through Tuesday.  The students were asked to make houses from children’s books.
There are 30 different houses, and the public is encouraged to go into the library and vote for their favorite creation.  Simply write the number of your favorite house on your ballot and place it in the box.  After January 6th the 1st, 2nd and 3rd prize winners will be named.
